title: Jesus Christ, ascension of
comment: The return of Jesus Christ to his Father in order to establish his kingdom, having completed his work on earth.

children.title: Jesus Christ, baptism of
children.comment: In obedience to God's will Jesus Christ was baptised in the River Jordan by John. The event was sealed by the descent of the Holy Spirit and the Father's voice of approval.

children.title: John tries to prevent Jesus Christ from being baptised

primaryrefs.comment: John was baptising repentant sinners but he knew that Jesus Christ was sinless.

children.title: The necessity of Jesus Christ's baptism
The events surrounding Jesus Christ's baptism
The baptism itself
Jesus Christ prays while being baptised
The Holy Spirit descends on Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: The Holy Spirit came upon Jesus Christ to equip him for his ministry which was about to begin and to give him strength at a time of temptation.

children.title: The voice of the Father is heard

primaryrefs.comment: These words, which are an allusion to Ps 2:7 and Isa 42:1, were repeated at the transfiguration.

children.title: Jesus Christ, birth of
children.comment: Jesus Christ was born to a poor unmarried Jewish couple in the village of Bethlehem. As Son of God, he was conceived by the Holy Spirit in the womb of his mother Mary.

children.title: Jesus Christ's birth is prophesied in the OT
The prophecy of a coming ruler
The prophecy of a virgin's son
The prophecy concerning his birthplace

primaryrefs.comment: ``Bethlehem Ephrathah'' is the village where David grew up (``the town of David'').

children.title: Jesus Christ was conceived by the Holy Spirit and born of a virgin
Jesus Christ's incarnation
The circumstances of Jesus Christ's birth
An angel informs Mary that she is to be the mother of the Messiah
Mary responds in praise
An angel explains to Joseph why Mary's baby is so special
The birth of Jesus Christ takes place
Angels announce Jesus Christ's birth to some shepherds
The Magi search for Jesus Christ's birthplace and Herod tries to kill him

secondaryrefs.comment: These events could have taken place at any time in Jesus Christ's first two years.

children.title: Jesus Christ, childhood of
children.comment: As an infant Jesus Christ was consecrated in the temple, accompanied by prophetic utterances regarding his future ministry. His childhood was characterised by a growth in wisdom and grace and, in particular, a strong desire to learn of God his Father and to understand the Scriptures.

children.title: Jesus Christ was consecrated as an infant
Indications of Jesus Christ's future ministry were revealed
Through the words of Simeon
Through the words of Anna
The visit of the Magi
The escape to Egypt
The return from Egypt
Jesus Christ lives in Nazareth
Jesus Christ grows up
Jesus Christ visited the temple
He celebrates the Passover there
He stays behind in the temple
He displays his understanding of the Scriptures there
The obedience of Jesus Christ
Mary and Joseph remember the sayings and events of Jesus Christ's childhood
Jesus Christ, cross of
children.comment: The death of Jesus Christ is of central importance to the Christian faith. Through Christ's death, sinners are reconciled to God and to their fellow human beings. Paul summarises the gospel as ``the message of the cross''.

children.title: Jesus Christ foretold his death on the cross
The facts of Jesus Christ's death on the cross
Carrying Jesus Christ's cross

primaryrefs.comment: Though Jesus Christ began to carry his cross, the Romans soon forced Simon of Cyrene to continue with it.

children.title: Jesus Christ refused the comfort of wine, which would have lessened the pains of his suffering
Jesus Christ was nailed to the cross
Jesus Christ's words from the cross
Signs accompanying Jesus Christ's death on the cross
children.precomment: Darkness over the whole land for three hours:

secondaryrefs.comment: the dead come back to life

children.title: People at the scene of the cross
children.precomment: The Roman centurion and his men:

secondaryrefs.comment: people who insulted and mocked Jesus Christ

children.title: Responsibility for the cross
The cross as God's plan
The crowd's call for Jesus Christ's crucifixion
Jewish and Roman leaders' responsibility
The triumph of the cross
The cross brings glory to Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ refers to his approaching death, the climax of his earthly life.

children.title: The cross brings reconciliation
Identification with the crucified Christ releases believers from their old way of life
Jesus Christ's cross is central to the Christian message
Jesus Christ's cross is the symbol of Christian discipleship
Jesus Christ, death of
children.comment: The death of Jesus Christ by crucifixion is of central importance to the NT. Through the faithful, obedient death of Christ, God grants sinners forgiveness and eternal life. The Christian sacraments of baptism and the Lord's Supper focus upon the death of Christ.

children.title: Jesus Christ's death was foretold
In time and in eternity
By Jesus Christ himself
Jesus Christ willingly planned to give his life
Plots to kill Jesus Christ
The manner of Jesus Christ's death
Jesus Christ died by crucifixion
The moment of death
Events accompanying Jesus Christ's death

secondaryrefs.comment: The curtain of the temple was split
The dead emerged from their tombs.

children.title: Jesus Christ's burial
The unique character of Jesus Christ's death
Jesus Christ's body did not decay
Jesus Christ descended to the dead
Jesus Christ was raised bodily from the dead
Death had no power over Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's death was a unique sacrifice
Achievements of Jesus Christ's death
Jesus Christ's death establishes the new covenant
Jesus Christ's death is a victory
Jesus Christ's death brings redemption
Jesus Christ's death brings forgiveness and cleansing
Jesus Christ's death brings sanctification
Believers identify with Jesus Christ in his death
Jesus Christ, family of
children.comment: Jesus Christ belonged to a human family and experienced family relationships during his earthly ministry. Such relationships underline the fact of Christ's humanity.

children.title: Jesus Christ was born into a family
He is placed in a family tree
His birth was a natural one

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's conception was miraculous, his birth natural.

seealsos.comment: see Lev 12:2-4 for the instructions concerning purification after childbirth

children.title: He grew up within a family
Jesus Christ's family is mentioned during his earthly ministry
Jesus Christ's natural brothers
James

primaryrefs.comment: This verse gives support to the traditional view that James, elder at Jerusalem and writer of the NT letter which bears his name was the Lord's brother. (Other references to him include Ac 15:13; 21:18; 1Co 15:7; Jas 1:1.).

children.title: Jude

seealsos.comment: Jude is understood to be a variation of Judas.

children.title: The nature of Jesus Christ's relationships with his family
He was obedient to and caring towards his parents
The will of his heavenly Father took precedence over the wishes of his natural family

primaryrefs.comment: In John's Gospel, Jesus Christ's ``time'' (or ``hour'') is his cross. Here Christ insists that only his heavenly Father can dictate the course of his ministry.

children.title: His family did not fully understand his ministry
Jesus Christ's natural family were among the first Christians
Jesus Christ, genealogy of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's human ancestry is traced back in two separate lines to David and thence back to Adam. Jesus' descent from David is of importance for his Messianic claims.

children.title: Jesus Christ is descended from Adam
Jesus Christ is descended from Abraham
Jesus Christ is descended from Isaac
Jesus Christ is descended from Jacob
Jesus Christ is descended from the tribe of Judah
Jesus Christ is descended from Jesse
Jesus Christ is descended from David
Jesus Christ's human lineage
Jesus Christ as the Son of David
Jesus Christ is greater than David
Jesus Christ is greater than Solomon
Jesus Christ as the son of Joseph and Mary
Jesus Christ, opposition to
children.comment: Jesus Christ encountered criticism, grumbling and plotting because he was seen as a threat to the religious and political hierarchy, and because he exposed sin.

children.title: Opposition by different groups
By family and friends
By religious leaders
By political leaders
Opposition through criticism and accusation
Criticism of Jesus Christ's choice of company
Criticism for breaking with tradition

secondaryrefs.comment: Though criticism is directed at the disciples, it is really against Jesus Christ

children.title: Accusations of Sabbath-breaking
Accusations of blasphemy
Accusations of being demon-possessed
Reasons for opposing Jesus Christ
Because of hatred
Because people's minds are closed
Jesus Christ knew where opposition would lead
Unsuccessful opposition before the crucifixion
Early attempts to arrest Jesus Christ
Attempts on Jesus Christ's life
Opposition that led to the crucifixion
Plots by the Jewish leaders
The chief priests stirred up the crowd
Rejection by political authorities
The mockery of the Roman soldiers
The betrayal by Judas Iscariot
Opposition at the crucifixion
Opposition to Jesus Christ in apostolic preaching
Saul of Tarsus opposes Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ, pre-existence of
Jesus Christ, resurrection appearances of
children.comment: Jesus Christ appeared to various groups and individuals on several occasions after his death, prior to his ascension into heaven.

children.title: The resurrection appearances of Jesus Christ on the third day
To Mary Magdalene
To the women at the tomb
To Peter
To the two travellers to Emmaus
To the disciples in the upper room
Further appearances of Jesus Christ
To the disciples in the upper room
Other appearances
Jesus Christ appears at his ascension
Jesus Christ's resurrection body
It was different from his pre-crucifixion body

primaryrefs.comment: This suggests that the resurrected body of Jesus Christ was not restricted by natural laws: closed doors provided no barrier to Jesus Christ's bodily appearance to his disciples.

seealsos.comment: The failure to recognise Jesus Christ may be an indication of his changed appearance but also might emphasise the disciples' own sorrow and lack of faith

children.title: It was a body of flesh and blood
Jesus Christ foretold his resurrection appearances
Responses to Jesus Christ's resurrection appearances
Fear and alarm
Doubt and disbelief
Belief and joy
Understanding and worship
The significance of Jesus Christ's resurrection appearances
They gave proof of Jesus Christ's deity
Christian life and faith depend on the trustworthiness of the witnesses' testimony
Jesus Christ, resurrection of
children.comment: True Christian preaching is centred on the fact that God raised Jesus Christ from the dead so that believers may have victory over sin and death and receive the blessings of eternal life.

children.title: The resurrection of Jesus Christ is foretold
In Scripture
By Jesus Christ
The resurrection is preached by the apostles
The certainty of the resurrection
The necessity of the resurrection
The results of Jesus Christ's resurrection
God's power is demonstrated
The sonship of Jesus Christ is declared
The lordship of Jesus Christ is declared
The destruction of death's power is declared
The benefits of Jesus Christ's resurrection for believers
It is the foundation of salvation
It provides the power to live for God
The intercession of Jesus Christ depends upon it
It brings assurance of resurrection to eternal life
Jesus Christ, second coming of
children.comment: Jesus Christ will return visibly and in glory at the end of history to raise the dead, judge the world, destroy all evil and opposition to God and consummate his kingdom. Believers are encouraged to be prepared for his return, waiting with eagerness and joy.

children.title: The second coming is foretold
In the OT
By Jesus Christ
By the angels at Jesus Christ's ascension
By the apostles
NT terms for the second coming
``Parousia''
children.precomment: Meaning literally ``presence'' or ``coming'', the term was used in the NT world of a royal visit:

children.title: ``Apocalypsis''
children.precomment: Meaning literally ``unveiling'', ``apocalypsis'' suggests that the second coming will make visible that which is already true of Jesus Christ but presently hidden from human sight:

children.title: ``Epiphaneia''
children.precomment: Meaning literally ``appearing'' or ``manifestation'', the term suggests coming out into view from a hidden background:

children.title: Events that will precede the second coming
The universal preaching of the gospel
The persecution of believers
Apostasy, nominal religion and godlessness
The revelation of the antichrist

primaryrefs.comment: The antichrist is a name given to the one who will lead opposition to God's kingdom.  It appears to refer to an individual but may denote a corporate movement.

children.title: The appearance of false Christs and false prophets
Wars and rumours of wars
Famines and earthquakes
Cosmic changes
The timing of the second coming
At God's appointed time
Unexpectedly
After a delay

primaryrefs.comment: Part of a parable concerning the coming of Jesus Christ who is represented by the bridegroom.

children.title: Imminently
The manner of the second coming
Jesus Christ's personal return
A visible and glorious return
With the sound of a trumpet
With angels
The purpose of the second coming
To raise the dead
To judge all people
To judge the wicked
To separate the wicked from the righteous
To destroy all evil and opposition to God's kingdom
To reward believers
To gather the church together
To bring final salvation
To transform the saints into his likeness
To end the present age
To restore and renew all things
Reactions at Jesus Christ's second coming
Present implications of the second coming for believers
They must always be watchful and ready
They must be faithful stewards
They must eagerly expect his coming
They must endure suffering with patient endurance
They must wait patiently
It is an incentive to holiness
It is an incentive to mission
Jesus Christ, suffering of
children.comment: Jesus Christ's life was characterised by suffering, though the worst experiences were reserved for his final days. His sufferings are both redemptive and an example to believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's sufferings foretold
In the OT
In Jesus Christ's predictions
Jesus Christ's suffering during his lifetime
As a child
Because of his family
Because of the crowds' unbelief
Because of the disciples' slowness
Because of the religious leaders
Because of human suffering
Jesus Christ's suffering at the time of his death
He was inwardly troubled
He was betrayed
He was humiliated
He was crucified
He suffered separation from God
Jesus Christ's attitude to his suffering
He did not retaliate in his suffering
He grew through the experience of suffering
Jesus Christ's sufferings were necessary for salvation
Jesus Christ suffered as a unique sacrifice
The Christian experience of suffering
Believers share in Jesus Christ's sufferings
Jesus Christ's sufferings are an example for believers
Jesus Christ, temptation of
children.comment: Repeated yet unsuccessful efforts made by Satan and by human beings to deflect Jesus Christ from his Father's will.

children.title: The wilderness temptations
Tempted to turn stones into bread
Tempted to abuse miraculous power
Tempted by the offer of an easy route to power
Tempted to doubt he was God's Son
Temptation continued throughout Jesus Christ's life

primaryrefs.comment: Trials can include temptations.

children.title: Opponents tempted Jesus Christ with trick questions
Jesus Christ tempted to sidestep the cross
Jesus Christ steadfastly resisted temptation
Jesus Christ resisted temptation by trusting God's word
Jesus Christ resisted temptation by obeying his Father
Results of Jesus Christ's temptations
Satan left Jesus Christ alone
Jesus Christ remained sinless

primaryrefs.comment: Refers to Jesus Christ as high priest and as sacrificial lamb.

children.title: Jesus Christ helps those who are being tempted
Jesus Christ, transfiguration of
children.comment: The revelation of the glory of Jesus Christ, shortly before his death, at which his disciples caught sight of him in his full majesty. The transfiguration brought home to the disciples that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.

children.title: The glory of Jesus Christ is revealed at the transfiguration
Jesus Christ prepares for his glory to be revealed
Jesus Christ is visibly transfigured

primaryrefs.comment: The transfiguration was a glimpse of Jesus Christ's glory whereby his physical appearance was visibly changed.

children.title: The disciples are eye-witnesses of Jesus Christ's glory
Moses and Elijah appear at the transfiguration

primaryrefs.comment: ``departure'' refers to Jesus Christ's death.

children.title: God's voice is heard at the transfiguration

primaryrefs.comment: God the Father's voice is heard authenticating Jesus Christ's ministry.

children.title: The disciples' response to the transfiguration
Peter's wish to build shelters
Fear
Questioning and confusion
They keep to themselves what they have seen and heard

primaryrefs.comment: These verses reiterate that Jesus Christ's full glory was hidden from the world until his resurrection.

children.title: Jesus Christ, trial of
children.comment: Jesus Christ, falsely accused of blasphemy towards God and treason towards Rome, humbly endured his trial as a fulfilment of the purposes of God.

children.title: The preliminary hearing before Annas

seealsos.comment: Annas, though deposed from office by the Romans, was probably still regarded by many as the true high priest

children.title: The trial before Caiaphas and the Sanhedrin
Jesus Christ is sent to the ruling high priest
False evidence is sought

primaryrefs.comment: The Sanhedrin was the high court of the Jews and consisted of 71 chief priests, elders and teachers of the law, including the high priest who presided.

children.title: False accusations are made

seealsos.comment: A person could only be convicted on the evidence of two or more witnesses.

children.title: Jesus Christ's trial centres upon his Messianic claims
Jesus declares himself to be the Christ
Jesus Christ is charged with blasphemy

secondaryrefs.comment: The Sanhedrin decided that Jesus Christ deserved death but charged him with treason rather than blasphemy.

children.title: Jesus is mocked as the Christ
The trial before Pilate
The Sanhedrin hand Jesus Christ over to Pilate
Jesus Christ accepts the title of king
Pilate decides Jesus Christ is innocent
Pilate sends Jesus Christ to Herod
Herod sends Jesus Christ back to Pilate
Pilate seeks to release Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: Pilate appeals to the crowd on the basis of Jesus Christ's kingship
Pilate is warned by his wife not to get involved

children.title: The crowd demand the release of Barabbas and the crucifixion of Jesus Christ
The crowd's demands prevail

seealsos.comment: The emphasis is on the people's responsibility.

children.title: Jesus Christ is mocked as king
Jesus Christ's response to his trial
Jesus Christ's trial confirms he is God's servant

seealsos.comment: The outcome of the trial fulfilled God's declared purpose.

children.title: Jesus Christ, triumphal entry of
children.comment: Jesus Christ rode into Jerusalem on a colt, royally yet humbly, to the rejoicing of his followers, but provoking opposition from the Jewish religious leaders.

children.title: The colt used in Jesus Christ's entry into Jerusalem
Jesus Christ's instructions to his disciples
The obedience of the disciples
Jesus Christ's entry into Jerusalem
The response of the crowd to Jesus Christ's entry into Jerusalem
Proclamation of Jesus Christ's kingship

secondaryrefs.comment: Spreading cloaks on the road was an act of royal homage.

children.title: Proclamation of Jesus' messiahship
Proclamation of Jesus Christ's victory

primaryrefs.comment: Palm branches were used in celebration of victory.

children.title: The response of the Pharisees to Jesus Christ's entry into Jerusalem

primaryrefs.comment: As in the OT, the cloud symbolises God's presence.

children.title: In the OT
Jesus Christ looks forward to his ascension as his return to his Father

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ establishes his kingdom by his ascension

children.title: He ascended to send the Holy Spirit
He ascended to prepare a place for his people
He ascended to exaltation and glory
